dmca.title: Copyright Infringement
dmca.body:
-----Original Message-----
From: roy@wasystems.net [mailto:roy@wasystems.net] 
Sent: Monday, September 27, 2004 5:15 PM
To: Legal Response
Subject: RE: Copyright Infringement

Here is a new/revised DMCA for you.


1. Electronic signature attached as JPG. -- Roy Camp  9/21/2004

2. The copyright and trademark infringement comprises the material appearing
on http://www.chattingaimbot.com.  Specific URL's will be given when
identifying each infringement on the offending site.

3. Copyright Infringements:
All of the data below has been verified as of 9/27/2004.

-- We understand that there is nothing wrong with someone creating a
competing duplicate of our service.  We do feel that the entire look and
feel of
their website is very mimicking of ours.  Being the service, as well as the
look
and feel, are exactly the same we are afraid that visitors that are looking
for
our site, may find their site and think we have merely made some design
changes. By visiting http://www.aimprank.com you will see their "use bot"
form.
 This is an exact copy of our form found at
http://chattingaimbot.com/?p=useb
with minor changes.  They have also mimicked our "bot status" page further
compounding the issue.  You can see this by comparing
http://aimprank.com/bot_status.php to ours at
http://chattingaimbot.com/?p=status.

-- The following are phrases that the bot says (The service we both provide
allows you to have a bot[computer] talk to your friend) when the
conversation
has been completed for one reason or another.  These phrases are unique
phrases we have developed and modified over the past year as part of
marketing
our service and bringing visitors back to our website.  There are two
separate
infringements.  In both case's they have been slightly modified (A couple
words different with a different URL) but it is still very clear it is
infringing of our marketing message's.
*The only way to see this for yourself is to signon AOL or AOL Instant
Messenger and have the bot's from both service's talk to you. For
convenience I
have taken a screenshot of both our's and his phrase's, but feel free to
test
the service's on yourself to verify the screenshots.*

This is our final message: http://chattingaimbot.com/chatbot1.jpg
This is their copied final message: http://chattingaimbot.com/aimprank1.jpg
A majority is exactly copied.

This is our "user did not respond" message:
http://chattingaimbot.com/chatbot2.jpg
This is their copied "user did not respond" message:
http://chattingaimbot.com/aimprank2.jpg


We want all of the above infringements to be fixed immediately as well as
immediate cease and desist of mimicking the "Chatting AIM Bot(s)"'s "use
bot" and "status" page, look and feel;  We are requesting the bot status
page be
removed altogether.  If these change's cannot be be done or
will not be done immediately we request the website,
http://www.aimprank.com, be
taken offline until proper change's are made.

Thank you for your assistance in this manner of protecting "Chatting AIM
Bot(s)"'s valuable intellectual property rights.


Further Information about the offender:
URL: http://www.aimprank.com
IP of website: 69.93.73.98
Information gathered from domain whois:
Demers, Morgan
 MindViz
500 East Ave.
Suite 5G
Rochester, NY  14610
US
585-586-3072



4. Contact Information:
Roy Camp
P.O. Box 26351
Fresno, CA. 93729
559-999-8218
roy@wasystems.net (Preferred method of contact.)

5.  I have a good faith belief that use of the copyrighted materials
described above on the allegedly infringing web pages is not authorized by
the
copyright owner, its agent, or the law.

The copyright infringements are not cleared under "fair use" (17 U.S.C.
Section 107) being it is a competing site of commercial nature operating as
an
exact replica of our service.  This is further reinforced by the fact that
all
infringing material is knowingly and directly copied from our website (word
for word in many cases).


6.  I swear, under penalty of perjury consistent with United States Code
Title 17, Section 512, that the information in the notification is accurate
and
that I am the copyright owner or am authorized to act on behalf of the owner
of
an exclusive right that is allegedly infringed.






Quoting Legal Response <legal-response@theplanet.com>:

> Please submit a new DMCA notice to us regarding this web site. We cannot
> take action without it. Thank you.
>
> Legal Response Team
> The Planet
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: roy@wasystems.net [mailto:roy@wasystems.net]
> Sent: Sunday, September 26, 2004 2:03 AM
> To: copyright@theplanet.com; abuse@theplanet.com
> Subject: Copyright Infringement
>
> Hello,
>    I have been in recent communication with ev1 abuse/DMCA agents
regarding
> a
> site that is committing trademark and copyright infringement.  They
> contacted
> the offender and the offender removed the 2 trademark infringements but is
> still
> violating 3 copyright infringement.  When I told ev1 he did not fully
remove
> all
> copyrighted material they relied with:
>
> Dear Mr. Camp,
>  Unfortunately, we no longer have and control over this situation as we no
> longer host the site.  Its now hosted by The Planet, who you can contact
at
> abuse@theplanet.com.
>
> Thank you,
> Janna
> EV1.net Abuse Team
> Abuse@ev1.net
> EV1Servers Abuse Team
> Abuse@ev1servers.net
>
>
> Apperantly he moved his site thinking he would be able to avoid making the
> rest
> of the changes.  I have contacted my lawyer of this new development and we
> might possibly be moving to take further legal action against the
offender.
> Hopefully you will be able help to help ASAP so we will not have to spend
> the
> time/money on that.  Below is the original (formal) DMCA I filed with ev1
as
> well as what the current status of the infringements are.
>
>
> Current Status (After reading the DMCA below this should make more sense):
>
> I have reviewed the offending site and confirmed the "Chatting AIM Bot(s)"
> trademark infringements have been removed.  I checked to see if the "no
> response" and "you have been pranked" message's were changed (the ones the
> bot
> say) and they have not been changed.  I have found the change's
> made to the "use bot" form found at http://www.aimprank.com to be somewhat
> unsatisfactory.  Further more, the "status page"
> http://aimprank.com/bot_status.php
> still looks exactly the same as ours,
> http://www.chattingaimbot.com/?p=status
> He can fully operate his service as normal without the copied "status
page".
> I
> am requesting the status page be fully removed from public view to stop
any
> confusion between his site and ours.  I have a feeling he did not change
the
> message's the bot says because he knew ev1 would not sign onto AOL/AIM and
> check... Then he moved servers to get ev1 off his back and thinking I
would
> not
> follow him.  Thank you for your assistance with this situation. Please
keep
> me
> updated.
>
>
> DMCA:
>
>
> 1. Electronic signature attached as JPG. -- Roy Camp  9/21/2004
>
> 2. The copyright and trademark infringement comprises the material
appearing
> on
> http://www.chattingaimbot.com.  Specific URL's will be given when
> identifying
> each infringement on the offending site.
>
> 3. Infringements.
> All of the data below has been verified as of 9/21/2004 1AM PST.
>
> Trademark Infringements:
> "Chatting AIM Bot(s)" has been our trademark for over a year and is well
> established (Chatting AIM Bot has appeared on TechTV, Wired.com and in
Maxim
> Magazine).  This trademark is used on the offending site in a manner which
> can
> easily be misconstrued and confuse visitors looking for our site.
>
> -- You can see by visiting our site (http://www.chattingaimbot.com)
Chatting
> AIM
> Bot is our trademark name.  At the bottom of the website we also state
> "Copyright C 2004 chattingaimbot.com. "Chatting AIM Bot(s)" is a trademark
> of
> WaSystems. All rights reserved."
> You can then see by visiting the offending site, http://www.aimprank.com
> that in
> the title bar of your internet browser (at the top) it says: "AIM Prank! -
> Trick
> your friends with our Chatting AIM Bots"
> At the same URL you can scroll down to the bottom of the page; Under "What
> is
> AIMPrank?" it says: "AIMPrank runs a variety of Chatting AIM Bots which
you
> can
> have Instant Message your friends."  Chatting AIM Bots is capitalized
> exactly
> how we use our trademark and even bolded.  Being their service was created
> as
> an exact copy of our service we find this to be very infringing on our
> trademark name.
>
>
> Copyright Infringements:
> -- We understand that there is nothing wrong with someone creating a
> competing
> duplicate of our service.  We do feel that the entire look and feel of
their
> website is very mimicking of ours.  Being the service, as well as the look
> and
> feel, are exactly the same we are afraid that visitors that are looking
for
> our
> site, may find their site and think we have merely made some design
changes.
> By

is
> an
> exact copy of our form found at http://chattingaimbot.com/?p=useb with
minor
> changes.  They have also mimicked our "bot status" page further
compounding
> the
> issue.  You can see this by comparing http://aimprank.com/bot_status.php
to
> ours
> at http://chattingaimbot.com/?p=status.
>

provide
> allows you to have a bot[computer] talk to your friend) when the
> conversation
> has been completed for one reason or another.  These phrases are unique

> words
> different with a different URL) but it is still very clear it is
infringing

> *The only way to see this for yourself is to signon AOL or AOL Instant
> Messenger

> a screenshot of both our's and his phrase's, but feel free to test the

> on yourself to verify the screenshots.*

> This is their copied final message:
http://chattingaimbot.com/aimprank1.jpg
